Dams and river diversions can have a significant impact on the migratory patterns of fish. When a dam is built or a river is diverted, it changes the flow of the river, which can disrupt the natural migration patterns of fish. For example, if a dam is built across a river, it can block the path of fish that are migrating upstream to spawn. This can cause a significant decline in fish populations, as many fish are unable to complete their migratory journey.

In addition to blocking the path of fish, dams and river diversions can also alter the temperature, depth, and flow of the water. This can affect the behavior and physiology of fish, making it more difficult for them to navigate the river and complete their migration. For example, changes in water temperature can impact the timing of fish migrations, as many species are sensitive to changes in temperature.

To mitigate the impacts of dams and river diversions on fish populations, a variety of strategies can be employed. These include the use of fish ladders, which help fish to bypass dams and other obstacles, as well as the establishment of fish hatcheries and the implementation of regulations on fishing practices. Additionally, efforts can be made to restore river habitats, such as the removal of dams and the planting of vegetation along riverbanks.
